Award.AwardTitle: Probing the Primordial Universe with the Large-Scale Structure and the CMB: from Systematic Errors to Fundamental Physics
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this program is to study the distribution of galaxies to test the assumption of statistical isotropy, which is the idea that the universe, on average, looks the same in every direction in the sky. A cosmological origin of the violation of statistical isotropy would invalidate basic assumptions used in the standard analyses to extract cosmological parameters. Dr. Huterer will explore numerically and analytically the use of large-scale structure data to probe inflationary physics in the presence of astrophysical and instrumental systematics.

Broader impacts of the work include training of undergraduate and graduate students. In addition, Dr. Huterer will run a two-week summer course for high school students as part of Michigan Math and Science Scholars program. He will also work with teachers in high-schools from the Detroit metro area, visiting their institutions, giving lectures in classes, and helping them develop astronomy curricula.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research supported by this grant concentrated on applying mathematical andstatistical methods to ameliorate the systematic errors in the distribution ofgalaxies -- that is, in the large-scale structure (LSS) of the universe. TheLSS measurements were then used to help shed light on the physical nature ofdark energy, a mysterious component which is responsible for the acceleratingexpansion of the universe.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT:

With grant-supported student Eduardo Ruiz, the PI carried out a novel andpowerful test of the consistency of the currently accepted cosmological modelwith cosmological constant as dark energy by separately measuring thegeometrical quantities and those describing the growth of structure incosmological observations. We found significant departures from the standardcorrespondence between the growth and geometry, and made connections withrelated findings in the literature which had framed the discrepancy in other,less transparent, terms.

With another grant-supported student Daniel Shafer, the PI studied thecalibration (systematic) errors in large-scale structure. These pernicioussystematics occur when the galaxy counts appear to vary as a function ofposition on the sky due to atmospheric conditions, avoidance of bright stars,imperfectly known Galactic dust, or a variety of other common effects. Weextended the development of the formalism that the PI established earlier,studied the so-called multiplicative calibration errors, and suggestedmethodologies to mitigate them.

Also with Shafer, the PI studied the most recent constraints on thecosmological parameters, and in particular the claimed discrepancies betweenPlanck and WMAP. These constraints had provided tantalizing evidence that thedark energy equation of state parameter is "phantom" (less than negative one). Weconfirmed these claims at face value, but found that they are notstatistically significant, unless if the Hubble constant turns out to behigh. Our work clarified the rather confusing prior state of affairs regardingthese particular questions.

With student Mijin Yoon, the PI constrained the statistical isotropy of theuniverse using the LSS. We measured the dipolar modulation of number counts ofgalaxies in the 2MASS-WISE survey. We also investigated how well a kinematicdipole -- the signature of our Galaxy's motion through the rest frame of thestructures at large -- can be detected with the next generation of LSS surveys.

With student Jessica Muir, the PI studied how well the late-time contributionto the cosmic microwave background (CMB) anisotropies -- the so-called IntegratedSachs-Wolfe contribution -- can be recovered from the LSS maps. We identified keysystematics in this procedure, quantified how they affect the results, andsuggested how to ameliorate them.

Finally, the PI and collaborators studied the ``CMB anomalies''. The anomaliesrefer to evidence that we and others originally found: that the angularcorrelation function of the WMAP experiment's temperature map vanishes onscales larger than 60 degrees, contrary to theoretical expectation; moreover,the largest structures in the CMB appear to be mutually aligned. We wrote apaper outlining how the physical mechanism behind the suppressed power can betested using CMB polarization observations. We also studied the lack oflarge-scale missing power and the alignments in the Planck data, findingresults broadly consistent with those in WMAP but with some interesting andpotentially revealing differences.


BROADER IMPACT:

This grant supported two graduate students, Eduardo Ruiz and Daniel Shafer,who received PhDs in 2014 and 2016, respectively. While students at Michigan,they worked closely with the PI who mentored them and helped them acquireindispensable research skills which they are now applying in their work as,respectively, a government lab scientist and a university postdoc.

The PI has also been running, for three years in a row, the Michigan Math andScience Scholars (MMSS) astronomy course.  The MMSS program represents amajor activity on University of Michigan's campus mid-summer every year, andits intensive two-week long courses in different fields of science aim toexpose a diverse group of high-school students to the sciences and provide amajor learning and hands-on experience. Huterer has been teaching the MMSScourse titled ``Climbing the Distance Ladder to the Big Bang: How AstronomersSurvey the Universe''. The course typically included around 16 high-schoolstudents from around the country (and typically several international studentsas well), and involved lectures, hands-on activities, sky observations andfield trips, and a final project whose results are displayed at UM's ``Diag''(center of the Central Campus).
